text: 1) Firearms It is generally agreed by most historians that black powder (called hwayak [화약/火藥] in Korean --literally, "fire medicine") was first developed by the Chinese probably sometime around the 9th century A.D., although there have been others who claim to have discovered it.103 Whatever the case might be, there is positive proof as to when black powder was first introduced to Korea. The first recorded instance of a firearm in Korea happened in 1356 when cannon, called chongtong, fired arrows as a demonstration for King Gongmin of the Goryeo dynasty. However, as China tightly controlled the technology for producing black powder, Korea had to obtain it from that country. That changed during the 3rd year of the reign of King Wu of Goryeo (1377) when a Korean, Choi Mu-seon, obtained the formula from a Chinese merchant, Lee Hang; Choi later traveled to China to learn firsthand firearm manufacturing techniques.104 (1) Cannons The firearms technology used by the Korean side was centuries old by the late 19th century and was a match for old foes of the 16th, 17th, and even 18th centuries; however, when coming up against an enemy using then-modern 19th century weapons, the contest
